title: 103_hr2609
content: The "Presidential Commission on TV Violence and Children Act" is established to address the widespread increase in violence and violent crime in the United States, particularly on television programming. Research shows a causal relationship between TV violence and violence in society, prompting the need for solutions to limit harmful influences while preserving freedom of expression. The Commission is tasked with investigating and proposing measures to address this issue. The Commission is responsible for reviewing findings on television violence's impact, gathering opinions from children, parents, and experts, and presenting comprehensive strategies to mitigate harmful effects while upholding free expression. The Commission, composed of the Surgeon General, the Attorney General, and 26 members appointed by the President, includes representatives from various groups such as broadcast television networks, parents organizations, and public health experts. Members serve for life, and vacancies are filled promptly. The Commission, composed of the Surgeon General, the Attorney General, and 26 members appointed by the President, includes representatives from various groups. Members serve for life and vacancies are filled promptly. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the term, members serve without pay, and travel expenses are provided. A majority of members is required for a quorum. The Commission, consisting of the Surgeon General, the Attorney General, and 26 appointed members, requires a majority for a quorum. The Surgeon General serves as chairperson, and the Attorney General as vice chairperson, with meetings called by the chairperson. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Commission, paid at the maximum rate of basic pay for GS-13. Additional staff may be appointed as needed, subject to civil service laws. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission upon request. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 7. The Commission, under Section 7 of the Act, has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain necessary information from government departments. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can also use the United States mails and receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within one year of appointment, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations to address television violence. The Commission will dissolve 6 months after submitting the report. $1,000,000 is authorized for this Act, subject to budget compliance.
